author: By Caitlin Macy
title: Summer After Summer, a Clan Returns to Cape Cod
description: In her debut novel, “The Paper Palace,” Miranda Cowley Heller follows an upper-crust family through decades at their bohemian backwoods compound.
content: THE PAPER PALACEBy Miranda Cowley Heller
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China Orders Didi Off App Stores in an Escalating Crackdown
description: The move comes two days after the government said it was investigating cybersecurity issues at the ride-hailing giant, which made its Wall Street debut this past week.
content: China’s government ordered the country’s leading ride-hailing platform, Didi, removed from app stores for “serious” problems related to the collection and use of customer data, the latest blow by Beijing to the company, which went public on the New York Stock Exchange just this past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Tyson Foods Recalls 8.5 Million Pounds of Frozen Chicken
description: The voluntary recall comes after the Agriculture Department linked three cases of listeriosis to the cooked chicken products, including one death.
content: Tyson Foods is recalling nearly 8.5 million pounds of frozen chicken that may have been contaminated with listeria, the Agriculture Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Met Opera Strikes Deal With Stagehands Over Pandemic Pay
description: The company now has agreements with two of its three largest unions, opening a path to reopening on schedule in September.
content: The Metropolitan Opera has reached a tentative agreement for a new contract with the union that represents its stagehands, increasing the likelihood that the company will return to the stage in September after its longest-ever shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Why America’s Politics Are Stubbornly Fixed, Despite Momentous Changes
description: The country is recovering from a pandemic and an economic crisis, and its former president is in legal and financial peril. But no political realignment appears to be at hand.
content: In another age, the events of this season would have been nearly certain to produce a major shift in American politics — or at least a meaningful, discernible one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: ‘Red Cradles’ Nurture China’s Next Generation of Communist Leaders
description: Communist Party schools and academies are inculcating Chinese officials in Xi Jinping Thought as the country shifts in a more authoritarian direction.
content: On a leafy campus in northwest Beijing, dotted with statues of Marx, Mao and other Communist saints, the Chinese leader Xi Jinping is training his “loyal successors,” the next generation of officials who will drive the resurgence of one-party rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Start With a Bang
description: The latest jobs report was good, consumer confidence is back and stocks are at record highs.
content: Happy Fourth of July. Between strong jobs growth in June, rising consumer confidence and a record-high stock market, there’s much to celebrate in the economy. So fire up the grill, watch the fireworks and enjoy the long holiday weekend. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Delia Fiallo, Master of the Telenovela, Is Dead at 96
description: She wrote more than 40 telenovelas, the American soap opera’s addictive cousin, and was one of the most celebrated names in Spanish-language television.
content: Delia Fiallo, the Cuban-born television writer known throughout Latin America as the “mother of the telenovela,” the addictively melodramatic Spanish-language cousin to the American soap opera, died on Tuesday at her home in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Philippine Military Plane Crashes With 96 People Aboard
description: At least 50 people, including three civilians on the ground, were killed in the accident, and it was feared that the toll would climb.
content: MANILA — A Philippine Air Force plane with 96 soldiers and crew members aboard crashed on the southern island of Jolo on Sunday, officials said. At least 50 people were killed, including three civilians on the ground, and it was feared that the toll would climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia, Adam Playford and Lazaro Gamio
title: Lax Enforcement Let South Florida Towers Skirt Inspections for Years
description: The collapse of Champlain Towers South has prompted a review of hundreds of older high-rises. Some buildings ignored or delayed action on serious maintenance issues.
content: Out of the smoke and cinders of a city convulsed by race riots and an immigration crisis, the towers kept rising, each new development remaking Miami’s skyline in the early 1980s and marking an ambitious bet that the battered community would turn itself around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Set yourself up with a holiday spread: hot dogs with pico de gallo, vegan cheeseburgers and much more.
content: Good morning. Happy Independence Day. You might start it by reading the Declaration of Independence, the document for which the holiday is named. There’ll be plenty time today for baseball and family reunions, sausages, blueberries, fireworks and flags. I’ve got loads to say about how to grill and what to grill. But take a minute now to read our origin story and reflect on the promises and pitfalls introduced that day in Philadelphia in 1776. It’s how it started. How it’s going is the business of news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Overnight Vaccination Drive in Rome Reaches Out to the ‘Most Fragile’
description: Nearly 900 people showed up for music, free espresso and cornetti, and a chance for protection against the coronavirus.
content: ROME — For months, Marta Pacholczak has been fretting about getting vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James S. Russell
title: A Glowing Shrine to the Printed Word
description: A mighty wall of books impresses in the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library, a transformed branch that bursts with new services and technology.
content: Muddling along for four decades in a nondescript former department store, the Mid-Manhattan library, at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street, served a growing swarm of local residents and commuters even as the branch steadily became a dilapidated “embarrassment” to the New York Public Library system, as Anthony W. Marx, its president, put it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A deadly plane crash in the Philippines.
content: A military plane in the Philippines crashed on Sunday, with 96 soldiers and crew on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: To Get Better at Being Single, Coco Gauff Is Making It a Double
description: The American teenager keeps winning at Wimbledon, and has used her doubles matches with Caty McNally to improve her tactics playing singles. She’s not the only one.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Coco Gauff, 17, and Roger Federer, 39, are at opposite ends of their playing careers, but they keep sharing the same highly desirable real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Fourth of July, Florida Condo Collapse, Stanley Cup: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Haircut Is Simple and the Same One I Have Been Getting for 11 Years’
description: The barbershop routine, a pricey cold drink and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Samuel Faust, Katie Dickerson Mayes and Céline Gounder
title: Covid Is a Greater Risk to Young People Than the Vaccines
description: The choice is between vaccinating or eventually getting infected.
content: The world got lucky: The toll of Covid-19 on young people and children has been much lower than it has been for adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj and Julie Turkewitz
title: Fraud Claims, Unproved, Delay Peru’s Election Result and Energize the Right
description: A month after polls closed, officials have yet to declare a victor in the presidential vote, as they consider Keiko Fujimori’s demand that ballots be thrown out.
content: LIMA, Peru — They showed up for the rally by the thousands in red and white, the colors of their right-wing movement, swapping conspiracy theories and speaking ominously of civil war, some brandishing shields with crosses meant to exalt European heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Her Family Owned Slaves. How Can She Make Amends?
description: Stacie Marshall, who inherited a Georgia farm, is trying on a small scale to address a generations-old wrong that still bedevils the nation.
content: DIRT TOWN VALLEY, Ga. — Just before people started to take the pandemic seriously, Stacie Marshall slipped into the back of a conference room in Athens, Ga., and joined two dozen Black farmers in a marketing seminar called “Collards Aren’t the New Kale.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Joao Silva
title: A Diamond Rush in South Africa, Born of Desperation and Distrust
description: When rumors of a diamond find hit social media, thousands of jobless South Africans rushed to a sleepy village. The government’s claim that the discovery was actually quartz was met with suspicion.
content: KWAHLATHI, South Africa — Sbusiso Molefe stretched the pickax high above his head and hacked into the clumpy black dirt around his feet. He took a few more vigorous whacks into the edges of the shallow crater he had dug at the bottom of a hillside, before scooping up a handful of loose dirt and shaking it in search of the sparkle of a gem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove, Frances Robles and Rick Rojas
title: Florida Officials Plan Swift Demolition of Remaining Part of Collapsed Building
description: The partially collapsed structure might not withstand a coming storm, officials fear.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Florida officials said on Saturday that they were rushing to demolish the part of the Champlain Towers South that remained standing, because they were fearful that the partially collapsed structure could not withstand the powerful winds of an approaching tropical storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Cox
title: Biden Is Missing Out on Something, and It’s Called a Deadline
description: Clear due dates are a powerful tool in our quest to get things done.
content: The first 100 days of Joe Biden’s presidency were a giddy time for Democrats. After being shut out of the White House for four years — and blocked from enacting their agenda since they lost control of the House of Representatives in 2010 — they came in hot, passing a $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief bill within weeks of the inauguration. As the clock ticked down to Day 100, Mr. Biden signed a stack of executive orders and, perhaps most important for a country staggering from the winter wave of the pandemic, easily met his promise of administering 200 million vaccine doses nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Investigating Amazon, the Employer
description: A recent Times project that examined how the tech giant manages its workers took months of reporting and hundreds of interviews.
content: Last summer, amid a hiring spree at Amazon so gigantic it left historians struggling for comparisons, Karen Weise, a Times reporter who covers the company from Seattle, brought up a puzzling question to her editors. Approaching the million-worker mark, Amazon was on track to becoming the largest private employer in the United States. Yet, in spite of solid wages and generous benefits, it was quickly cycling through employees. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter Reflect on 75 Years of Marriage
description: Their relationship has been a constant through wins and losses, reinvention and raising a family. At 96 and 93, they have come to rely on their bond more now than ever.
content: PLAINS, Ga. — Jimmy Carter, a midshipman in the U.S. Naval Academy, wanted to marry Rosalynn Smith, a girl he met on the day she was born and knew mostly as his sister Ruth’s best friend until they went on a double date, riding to the movies together squeezed in the rumble seat of an old Ford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gioconda Belli
title: Daniel Ortega and the Crushing of the Nicaraguan Dream
description: The country has elections this fall, but its president keeps jailing the opposition.
content: Will they come for me? What will it be like to be jailed by the same people I fought alongside to topple the 45-year Somoza dictatorship in Nicaragua, my country?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: The company hired to take down the damaged Surfside building is known for the Seattle Kingdome implosion.
description: The company was also involved in work at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building after the Oklahoma City bombing and on the World Trade Center after the attack on Sept. 11.
content: Controlled Demolition Inc., the company hired to demolish the remaining section of the Champlain Towers South condo, has more than 70 years of experience bringing down some of the world’s biggest structures, including the Seattle Kingdome in 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar
title: Indian police investigate whether scammers gave thousands of shots of salt water instead of vaccine.
description: Fourteen people have been charged with conspiracy and forgery, the latest example of fraud undermining India’s pandemic response.
content: As India intensifies its vaccination effort amid fears of another wave of the coronavirus, officials are investigating allegations that perhaps thousands of people were injected with fake vaccines in the financial capital, Mumbai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: The Tech Cold War’s ‘Most Complicated Machine’ That’s Out of China’s Reach
description: A $150 million chip-making tool from a Dutch company has become a lever in the U.S.-Chinese struggle. It also shows how entrenched the global supply chain is.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — President Biden and many lawmakers in Washington are worried these days about computer chips and China’s ambitions with the foundational technology.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: On July Fourth, Stars and Stripes and Division
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 4, 2021.
content: “There is a lot of history with this country, some that maybe people don’t like today, and some that people are being judged for today for what they did 300 years ago. It’s still our country and every good and bad thing made it our country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Francis Undergoes Colon Surgery and Is Said to Be Doing Well
description: It is the first time that Francis has been admitted to a hospital since becoming pope in 2013.
content: ROME — The Vatican announced that Pope Francis had responded well to colon surgery in a hospital in Rome on Sunday evening, overcoming the first significant health challenge in a pontificate that has lasted more than eight years and shifted the priorities and direction of the Roman Catholic Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: For the Milwaukee Bucks, the Jrue Holiday Gamble Yielded a Jackpot
description: When the Bucks acquired Holiday, it was hardly clear that they had solved their problems and improved their chances of enticing Giannis Antetokounmpo to stay.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks were in an unusual position during the last off-season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: BoltBus, Favorite of Frugal Riders, Suspends Service Indefinitely
description: The shutdown comes just as domestic travelers are getting back on the road.
content: BoltBus, the bus service known for offering its passengers Wi-Fi and $1 lottery seats, is shutting down operations indefinitely after months of low ridership during the pandemic, according to Greyhound, its parent company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: A Disparaging Video Prompts Explosive Fallout Within ESPN
description: In comments still rippling through the network, the reporter Rachel Nichols, who is white, said Maria Taylor, who is Black, earned the job to host 2020 N.B.A. finals coverage because ESPN was “feeling pressure” on diversity.
content: As the N.B.A. playoffs started in May, the stars of ESPN’s marquee basketball show, “NBA Countdown,” discussed whether they would refuse to appear on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Bucks Beat Hawks and Advance to the N.B.A. Finals
description: Milwaukee was playing without its injured star, Giannis Antetokounmpo. The Bucks will face the Phoenix Suns in the finals.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks advanced to their first N.B.A. finals since 1974 after defeating the Atlanta Hawks, 118-107, in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals Saturday night to take the series, four games to two. They will face the Phoenix Suns in the N.B.A. finals starting Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annette Gordon-Reed
title: Between Juneteenth and the Fourth of July
description: Both holidays are wholly American. Both holidays belong to all of us.
content: When I was growing up, my family celebrated Juneteenth and the Fourth of July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Mitch Smith
title: For Mayor Daniella Levine Cava, announcing the painful toll is part of the job.
description: The mayor of Miami-Dade County, little known outside Florida before the Surfside collapse, has helped the world track the number of dead and missing.
content: At almost every news conference, Mayor Daniella Levine Cava steps to the microphone and delivers awful news: The number of people known to have died in the condo collapse in Surfside, Fla. — and the even larger number who are still missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Seeks to Soften Blow of U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: Keeping the top commander in the country longer is part of an effort to reassure Afghans as the Taliban step up their offensive.
content: WASHINGTON — When Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III convened his military brain trust last Thursday on a classified videoconference for an update on Afghanistan, commanders had reason to feel positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: As Secular Peace Effort Stutters in Israel, Religious Mediators Hope to Step In
description: The inclusion of an Islamist party in Israel’s government has spurred a group of imams and rabbis hoping to build a religious-based peace movement.
content: JERUSALEM — The rabbi stood before the grave of the imam, weeping as he gave his eulogy. In life, Rabbi Michael Melchior said, Sheikh Abdullah Nimr Darwish had promised him that he would never leave his side. In death, the sheikh had left him feeling as bereft as an orphan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: Simone Biles Is Redefining Female Power in Sports
description: The record-breaking gymnast is forging a path beyond girlhood for her sport.
content: As we head into the 2021 Olympics, I have often recalled being a 12-year-old watching the American Olympic gymnasts at the 1996 Atlanta Games vault and soar and flip their way to victory. Those girls were just a little older than me, but they were so small. You could see their muscles moving under their skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Axelrod
title: When It Comes to People Like My Daughter, One Size Does Not Fit All
description: Federal funding should not automatically favor smaller settings over larger ones for people with disabilities.
content: My daughter, Lauren, turned 40 last month. She is happy and healthy. And that is nothing short of a miracle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Should People With Immune Problems Get Third Vaccine Doses?
description: France is handing out third shots of the two-dose vaccines to cancer patients and others with immune system impairments. In the United States, patients like these are on their own.
content: When it came to coronavirus vaccination, the third time was the charm for Esther Jones, a dialysis nurse in rural Oregon. After two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine failed to jolt her immune system into producing antibodies, she sought out a third, this time the Moderna shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Despite What It’s Called
description: Peter Gordon writes letters to solvers.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Peter Gordon, a veteran constructor who is making his 122nd (!!!) appearance in the New York Times Crossword today, knows a thing or two about letters. Along with the constructor Frank Longo, Mr. Gordon publishes a set of A-to-Z Crosswords for subscribers that are all pangrams (that is, they incorporate every letter of the alphabet at least once).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In Another Yankees Collapse, No Mercy From the Mets or the Home Crowd
description: In the first game of a doubleheader on Sunday, the Mets rallied for six runs in the final inning for a 10-5 victory at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees got a much-needed win in the second game.
content: There are times when the local television broadcasters are best suited to provide the most accurate accounting of a baseball team’s performance. They watch every game and are naturally inclined to unearth the most favorable perspectives, if possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Celebrates Progress Against Virus, but Acknowledges Hurdles Ahead
description: The White House hosted an Independence Day event to signal the administration’s headway against the pandemic, but it was still far from a victory pronouncement.
content: WASHINGTON — On the day that President Biden had long anticipated as a milestone in the fight against the coronavirus, the White House hosted a celebration to both commemorate the July 4 holiday and herald the administration’s progress toward overcoming the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Tropical Storm Elsa Leaves 3 Dead in the Caribbean
description: The storm killed at least three people over the weekend in the Dominican Republic and St. Lucia, after it slammed the eastern Caribbean islands as the first hurricane of the 2021 Atlantic season.
content: The storm killed at least three people over the weekend in the Dominican Republic and St. Lucia, after it slammed the eastern Caribbean islands as the first hurricane of the 2021 Atlantic season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 4, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 4, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s plan to increase electric car sales referred imprecisely to the mileage rating of the Ford F-150. While the hybrid version gets roughly 25 miles to the gallon, the basic model gets only about 20 miles per gallon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Officers Leave the Police Force
description: Readers discuss a problem that was magnified last year by charges of police misconduct. Also: Choosing family size.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
